description: From Middle English scabard, scauberde, scauberk, scauberke, from Anglo-Norman eschaubert, escalberc, of Germanic origin, perhaps from Frankish *skarberg (“sheath”, literally “blade-protection”), from Proto-Germanic *skēriz (“blade, scissors”) + *bergaz (“shelter, protection, refuge”). See also hauberk.

verbs.description: scabbard (third-person singular simple present scabbards, present participle scabbarding, simple past and past participle scabbarded)

entries.meaning: To put an object (especially a sword) into its scabbard.
